<td style="padding-top:20px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning. </strong>We’ve got something a little different planned for you this week. In the Week Ahead section, we often include different economic data releases like “ISM Manufacturing Index” or “beige book.” We imagine many of you skip over those, not fully understanding what they are and why they matter.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So, each day this week, we’re going to spend some time explaining those reports, culminating on Friday with the biggest economic data point of them all—the monthly jobs numbers.</p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GROCERY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/01/trader-joes-founder-dies-leaving-behind-giant-retail-legacy?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Trader Joe’s and the Golden Age of Private Label
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Trader Joe's storefront " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MS90cmFkZXJfam9lX3MuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Getty Images/Melissa Renwick</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Shopping at Trader Joe’s, a weekend ritual for so many Americans, was a little more subdued this weekend. Founder Joe Coulombe <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/29/business/joe-coulombe-dead.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">died on Friday</a> at 89.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Coulombe built a grocery brand that borders on cult status. True story: One Brew writer limited her apartment search to buildings within a few blocks of a Trader Joe’s. And at least in New York City, the crowds are so huge you do most of your shopping while waiting in line for the register. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">How that happened</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In the mid-’60s, Coulombe owned a bunch of convenience stores in the LA area. But when 7-Eleven entered the market, he knew he simply <a href="https://apnews.com/7e58cf76e73aba70736081a06e2715fa?utm_campaign=SocialFlow&utm_source=Twitter&utm_medium=APWestRegion&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">could not compete</a> with its scale and rotisserie taquitos. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So in 1967, Coulombe opened the first Trader Joe’s in Pasadena, CA. There was no grocery store like it—staff in Hawaiian shirts, exotic food products, and cheap wine for days. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“He grafted the gourmet store onto the convenience store onto the health food store onto the liquor store,” Los Angeles Magazine wrote in 2011. All with a weird-but-it-works South Seas vibe.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Coloumbe sold his interest in Trader Joe’s to German supermarket chain Aldi in 1979 and retired nine years later. Now, Trader Joe's has over 500 locations nationwide. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The industry impact</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Trader Joe’s has <a href="https://www.eater.com/2017/8/9/16099028/trader-joes-products?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">perfected the art</a> of the “private label,” when a retailer contracts directly with manufacturers to sell products under its own brand name (think Room Essentials by Target). </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>With private label brands, you get differentiation, more control of production, and higher margins. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>But...shunning popular brand names is risky. A startup literally named Brandless </span><span><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/10/softbankbacked-brandless-closes-shop?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">shut down</a></span><span> just a few weeks ago. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Still, the grocery industry appears to be moving down the path carved by Trader Joe’s. Big names like Target, Albertsons, and Kroger are all <a href="https://www.emarketer.com/content/retailers-are-revamping-private-label-grocery?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">refreshing</a> their private label offerings to appeal to millennials—the generation most likely to eat Crispy Hexagons cereal if it’s the right price.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
INVESTING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/01/elliott-pushes-changes-twitter?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
When a Firm Named Elliott Tells You What to Do
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It hurts. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On Friday, <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-29/singer-s-elliott-is-said-to-seek-to-replace-twitter-ceo-dorsey?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Bloomberg reported rumblings</a> of a c-suite showdown at Twitter. Activist hedge fund Elliott Management has reportedly:  </p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Taken a $1 billion stake</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Nominated four directors to the board </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Spoken with management about getting a full-time CEO </span></li>
</ol>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Doesn’t Twitter have a CEO? </strong>Twitter is Jack Dorsey’s side hustle. He also runs the fintech company Square and tweeted in November that he wanted to live in Africa for three to six months this year. Shareholders did not love that. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Where you know Elliott from: </strong>The firm has recently bought chunks of, <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/elliott-management-nominates-four-directors-to-twitters-board-11583015770?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">then played hardball with</a>, household names like AT&T and eBay. Thus far, it hasn’t brandished its favorite weapon—taking management fights public—against Twitter. But that could change. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>While Twitter is the platform of choice for media elites’ <a href="https://twitter.com/Neal_Freyman/status/1225021371673120768?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">musings on underrated snacks</a>, it’s not a financial juggernaut. Shares are down 6.2% since Dorsey’s 2015 return and Twitter airballed Q3 earnings in October.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RETAIL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/01/new-yorks-plastic-bag-ban-goes-effect?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Yes We Ban
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="plastic bag floating in the wind" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=504 src="https://oslo-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/medium/asset/56/plastic_bag.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="plastic bag floating in the wind" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://oslo-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/medium/asset/56/plastic_bag.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We never knew <span>so many of our coworkers had canvas totes</span>, but they’re all over the office today. On Sunday, New York State’s ban on most types <span>of single-use plastic bags </span>went <a href="https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/new-york-states-plastic-bag-ban-goes-into-effect/2307905/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">into effect</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">There's a little more to the story, though.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>A plastic bag manufacturer and an association of NYC convenience store owners </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/new-york-state-delays-enforcement-of-plastic-bag-ban-after-lawsuit-is-filed-11582929834?mod=searchresults&page=1&pos=1&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">filed a lawsuit</a></span><span> on Friday challenging the law. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>So the state decided to hold off on levying penalties until April 1, making the law effectively toothless until the weather gets a bit nicer. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory:</strong> The State Assembly passed the law last March, following in California’s footsteps. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The case for the ban: </strong>New Yorkers use an estimated 23 billion nonbiodegradable single-use plastic bags every year. 85% of them are discarded, freeing them to clog streams and rivers, harm wildlife, litter cities, and play central roles in <a href="https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0169547/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">creepy movies</a>. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The case against:</strong> Opponents say the ban unfairly harms small businesses and low-income people. Frank Garcia of the National Association of the Latino State Chambers said of NYC’s beloved bodegas, “They’re not gonna survive.” </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPONSORED BY THE ASCENT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
I’m Building a Roller Coaster With my Cash Back Credit Card
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Stop with the eye-rolling. Yeah, I may not have the structural engineering “know-how” all you naysayers think I need, but I do have a <a href="https://www.fool.com/mms/mark/the-ascent-discb-landing-page/?utm_site=theascent&utm_campaign=ta-cc-co-mb-discb-03022020-5-na-word&utm_medium=cpc&utm_source=mb" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">credit card</a> with <strong style="color:#000">up to 5% cash back and 0% intro APR until 2021</strong>. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://www.fool.com/mms/mark/the-ascent-discb-landing-page/?utm_site=theascent&utm_campaign=ta-cc-co-mb-discb-03022020-5-na-word&utm_medium=cpc&utm_source=mb" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">This credit card</a> is going to help me cover everything in terms of R&D, lumber, labor, and all the zoning fines I’m guaranteed to incur from city officials. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In fact, I’m slated to lock in <strong style="color:#000">$1,148 (maybe more)</strong> to put towards my roller coaster without paying a dime for an annual fee.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">While your dreams may not be as delightfully eccentric as mine, I’m sure you’re eyeing something special (like a new fence to block the view of your neighbor’s new backyard roller coaster).</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://www.fool.com/mms/mark/the-ascent-discb-landing-page/?utm_site=theascent&utm_campaign=ta-cc-co-mb-discb-03022020-5-na-word&utm_medium=cpc&utm_source=mb" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Whatever it is, this card can help you get there</a>.</p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</th>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/01/questions-ism-manufacturing-report-answered?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
ISM Manufacturing Report: The Super Bowl of Supply Chain
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We’re kicking off our weeklong series on actually understanding economic data releases with the <a href="https://www.instituteforsupplymanagement.org/ISMReport/MfgROB.cfm?SSO=1&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">ISM Manufacturing Report</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Frequency: </strong>It’s released on the first business day of each month at 10am ET. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Who’s doing the releasing: </strong>The Institute for Supply Management (ISM), a supply chain nonprofit with 50,000 members. Turning 105 this year, the ISM says it’s the first supply management institute in the world. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How they do it: </strong>The ISM surveys hundreds of supply chain execs about specifics like new orders, production, and inventories. The ISM then wraps up the responses to create the Purchasing Manager’s Index (PMI), an easily digestible number that can be tracked over time. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Who cares: </strong>Everyone. Manufacturing accounts for 11% of U.S. GDP, so getting a good read on the industry tells us important information about the broader economy.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Where we stand now: </strong>The PMI showed a reading of 50.9 for January, the <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/03/ism-manufacturing-index-january-2020.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">highest level</a> since July 2019. A PMI reading of more than 50 means the country's manufacturing sector is growing. Under 50 means it’s shrinking.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">
<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F03%2F01%2Fquestions-ism-manufacturing-report-answered" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We expect to hear the word "coronavirus" in virtually every report listed below.</p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Wednesday: </strong>Fed beige book; earnings (Zoom) </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Thursday: </strong>OPEC meeting in Vienna; NASA announces name of Mars rover; Spotify Awards in Mexico City; earnings (Kroger) </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Friday: </strong>Hillary Clinton doc becomes available on Hulu; February jobs report; make sure your boss knows it’s Employee Appreciation Day </p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On Saturday, we asked readers whether the coronavirus was affecting their day-to-day work lives. About 15% of respondents said it was, and here are a few of their stories:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“I’m a firefighter/EMT and people call 911 when they sneeze and assume it’s the virus.”</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“I work at the NYSE, so that’s been fun…”</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“So. Much. Planning. I work on a large, busy healthcare campus. Everything from manufacturers price gouging & hoarding normal medical supplies to how are we going to handle DoorDash deliveries are topics of conversations.”</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“I work in South Korea. We have to wear masks in all public places, on shuttle buses, at meetings. People avoid face to face meetings.”</span></li>
</ul>

width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MS90cmFkZXJfam9lX3MuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGetty Images/Melissa Renwick\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eShopping at Trader Joe’s, a weekend ritual for so many Americans, was a little more subdued this weekend. Founder Joe Coulombe \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/29/business/joe-coulombe-dead.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edied on Friday\u003c/a\u003e at 89.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eCoulombe built a grocery brand that borders on cult status. True story: One Brew writer limited her apartment search to buildings within a few blocks of a Trader Joe’s. And at least in New York City, the crowds are so huge you do most of your shopping while waiting in line for the register. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eHow that happened\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn the mid-’60s, Coulombe owned a bunch of convenience stores in the LA area. But when 7-Eleven entered the market, he knew he simply \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/7e58cf76e73aba70736081a06e2715fa?utm_campaign=SocialFlow\u0026utm_source=Twitter\u0026utm_medium=APWestRegion\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecould not compete\u003c/a\u003e with its scale and rotisserie taquitos. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSo in 1967, Coulombe opened the first Trader Joe’s in Pasadena, CA. There was no grocery store like it—staff in Hawaiian shirts, exotic food products, and cheap wine for days. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“He grafted the gourmet store onto the convenience store onto the health food store onto the liquor store,” Los Angeles Magazine wrote in 2011. All with a weird-but-it-works South Seas vibe.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eColoumbe sold his interest in Trader Joe’s to German supermarket chain Aldi in 1979 and retired nine years later. Now, Trader Joe's has over 500 locations nationwide. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe industry impact\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eTrader Joe’s has \u003ca href=\"https://www.eater.com/2017/8/9/16099028/trader-joes-products?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eperfected the art\u003c/a\u003e of the “private label,” when a retailer contracts directly with manufacturers to sell products under its own brand name (think Room Essentials by Target). \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWith private label brands, you get differentiation, more control of production, and higher margins. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eBut...shunning popular brand names is risky. A startup literally named Brandless \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/10/softbankbacked-brandless-closes-shop?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eshut down\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e just a few weeks ago. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eStill, the grocery industry appears to be moving down the path carved by Trader Joe’s. Big names like Target, Albertsons, and Kroger are all \u003ca href=\"https://www.emarketer.com/content/retailers-are-revamping-private-label-grocery?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erefreshing\u003c/a\u003e their private label offerings to appeal to millennials—the generation most likely to eat Crispy Hexagons cereal if it’s the right price.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt hurts. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOn Friday, \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-29/singer-s-elliott-is-said-to-seek-to-replace-twitter-ceo-dorsey?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eBloomberg reported rumblings\u003c/a\u003e of a c-suite showdown at Twitter. Activist hedge fund Elliott Management has reportedly:  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003col\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eTaken a $1 billion stake\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eNominated four directors to the board \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSpoken with management about getting a full-time CEO \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ol\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eDoesn’t Twitter have a CEO? \u003c/strong\u003eTwitter is Jack Dorsey’s side hustle. He also runs the fintech company Square and tweeted in November that he wanted to live in Africa for three to six months this year. Shareholders did not love that. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhere you know Elliott from: \u003c/strong\u003eThe firm has recently bought chunks of, \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/elliott-management-nominates-four-directors-to-twitters-board-11583015770?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethen played hardball with\u003c/a\u003e, household names like AT\u0026T and eBay. Thus far, it hasn’t brandished its favorite weapon—taking management fights public—against Twitter. But that could change. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eWhile Twitter is the platform of choice for media elites’ \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/Neal_Freyman/status/1225021371673120768?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emusings on underrated snacks\u003c/a\u003e, it’s not a financial juggernaut. width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWe never knew \u003cspan\u003eso many of our coworkers had canvas totes\u003c/span\u003e, but they’re all over the office today. On Sunday, New York State’s ban on most types \u003cspan\u003eof single-use plastic bags \u003c/span\u003ewent \u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/new-york-states-plastic-bag-ban-goes-into-effect/2307905/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003einto effect\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThere's a little more to the story, though.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eA plastic bag manufacturer and an association of NYC convenience store owners \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/new-york-state-delays-enforcement-of-plastic-bag-ban-after-lawsuit-is-filed-11582929834?mod=searchresults\u0026page=1\u0026pos=1\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efiled a lawsuit\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e on Friday challenging the law. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSo the state decided to hold off on levying penalties until April 1, making the law effectively toothless until the weather gets a bit nicer. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory:\u003c/strong\u003e The State Assembly passed the law last March, following in California’s footsteps. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe case for the ban: \u003c/strong\u003eNew Yorkers use an estimated 23 billion nonbiodegradable single-use plastic bags every year. 85% of them are discarded, freeing them to clog streams and rivers, harm wildlife, litter cities, and play central roles in \u003ca href=\"https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0169547/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecreepy movies\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe case against:\u003c/strong\u003e Opponents say the ban unfairly harms small businesses and low-income people. Frank Garcia of the National Association of the Latino State Chambers said of NYC’s beloved bodegas, “They’re not gonna survive.” \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable Chain\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWe’re kicking off our weeklong series on actually understanding economic data releases with the \u003ca href=\"https://www.instituteforsupplymanagement.org/ISMReport/MfgROB.cfm?SSO=1\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eISM Manufacturing Report\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eFrequency: \u003c/strong\u003eIt’s released on the first business day of each month at 10am ET. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWho’s doing the releasing: \u003c/strong\u003eThe Institute for Supply Management (ISM), a supply chain nonprofit with 50,000 members. Turning 105 this year, the ISM says it’s the first supply management institute in the world. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow they do it: \u003c/strong\u003eThe ISM surveys hundreds of supply chain execs about specifics like new orders, production, and inventories. The ISM then wraps up the responses to create the Purchasing Manager’s Index (PMI), an easily digestible number that can be tracked over time. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWho cares: \u003c/strong\u003eEveryone. Manufacturing accounts for 11% of U.S. GDP, so getting a good read on the industry tells us important information about the broader economy.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhere we stand now: \u003c/strong\u003eThe PMI showed a reading of 50.9 for January, the \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/03/ism-manufacturing-index-january-2020.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehighest level\u003c/a\u003e since July 2019. A PMI reading of more than 50 means the country's manufacturing sector is growing. Under 50 means it’s shrinking.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: About 15% of respondents said it was, and here are a few of their stories:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“I’m a firefighter/EMT and people call 911 when they sneeze and assume it’s the virus.”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“I work at the NYSE, so that’s been fun…”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“So. Much. Planning. I work on a large, busy healthcare campus.
